Buy Strife: Veteran Edition

$9.99
Add to Cart
 

Recommended By Curators

"One of the very first RPGs with guns is back. Deep and dark story with NPCs, c&c, FPS-action, some character building - good game using the Doom engine!"

About This Game

The Original Strife is back!


Hailed as the original FPS-RPG game that spawned countless imitators, Strife: Veteran Edition is a love letter to the classic from 1996.

New Features Include:

  • Support for high resolutions, with proper aspect ratio.
  • OpenGL for video backend to provide portability and support for vertical sync.
  • Dynamic lighting and bloom
  • Widescreen support.
  • Ability to freely rebind all keyboard, mouse, and gamepad inputs.
  • Steam Achievements
  • Steam Trading Cards

Completion of missing and unfinished options in the original game, such as:

  • The planned "Capture the Chalice” multi-player mode.
  • Marking of current objectives on the auto-map.
  • Special HUD for the Torpedo weapon



Immerse yourself in this all-consuming epic quest that for the first time combines riveting role-playing adventure with the spectacular Doom 3D engine! -An evil presence has implanted itself in the fabric of our world. Play the role of spy, assassin, warrior and thief as you are lured into the darkest and most perilous adventure of your life. You´ll have Blackbird on your side - a seductive underground agent that will provide you with clues as you encounter progressively more sinister foes. Be strong, and trust no one.

FULLY INTERACTIVE WORLD
The elaborate virtual environment offers 28 interconnected levels covering over 200 square miles. Explore medieval towns and industrial complexes filled with pitfalls and perils, ending in a final confrontation that will reveal the planet's darkest secrets.

AN AWESOME ARSENAL
From the silent but lethal crossbow to the breathtaking flame thrower, you'll toast, mince and vaporize your opponents in your search to control the ultimate weapon of mass destruction- the Sigil.

NAIL-BITING NARRATIVE
In your role as resistance fighter, you'll conspire with allies to demolish the fanatical ranks of the order from the inside out. Provides an engaging complex storyline and a multitude of dramatic voice-overs.

READ MORE

8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
nek♥|Guineu
1,488 products in account
16 reviews
Recommended
17.4 hrs on record
Posted: July 28
One of the first games ever to mix the FPS genre with RPG elements and even some stealth. Think of it as the grandfather of games like the original Deus Ex, System Shock 2 or the original Thief.

About the original game

Interesting scifi/fantasy world. Levels are connected by a hub system instead of being linear one after the other; you start in a town and from there you can go to many different areas, some of them opening up as you advance the story. You will be given missions to complete, that's how you advance the story. Depending on some decisions the story will have minor forks. Some quests can be completed going stealth but in other cases you have to go full postal. Nice variety of weapons, from a stealthy crossbow to a destructive BFG-like thingy.
Other RPG elements in the game: leveling up system even if it's very simple, item stores, inventory system, plenty of NPCs to interact with...

About the "Veteran Edition" release

But wait, that's not all, Night Dive Studios has done an excellent job improving the game for the "Veteran Edition" version: support for higher resolutions more fitting for current day monitors, a whole new optional area in the story, a few new secrets (hidden talismans), multiplayer support (capture the chalice), steam achievements...

Overall, Strife is an underappreciated timeless classic, one of those games every "gamer" should have played. I want to go back to the 90s.

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
BetrayDay2
1,475 products in account
63 reviews
Recommended
10.8 hrs on record
Posted: May 22
98%

I am the sort of person who becomes incredibly enamored with 90's FPSes. Seeing my favourite genre of immersive media in its period of infancy, where the developers were still learning what works and what doesn't... There is just something magical about it, like watching old black and white movies and insisting they're better in every way to the stuff released today.

Of course they aren't. No movie buff is right when they say Kubrick's works outshine the oscarbait we get in our current decade, no photographer is right when they say pictures just look better taken with their analogue sh**boxes. We see the past with rose-tinted glasses because of many factors; nostalgia, passion, auteur admiration, but none of these make the works of the past outright better. I am saying this to quality my recommendation, because Strife was made in 1996; the games industry has had almost 20 years to innovate since this game was released, and as such, as good as the game is, is just can't outshine IPs such as half-life or the elder scrolls series.

That being said, I now feel comfortable telling you that this game is probably one of the best games I have ever played.

Strife is made on a heavily modified DOOM engine, but it plays closer to 3Drealms' Duke 3D or Shadow Warrior; you can jump, run, fill your inventory with all manner of useful gadgets, and best of all, the game contains the first example of RPG elements in an FPS game; you level up doing sidequests, you can find gold in secret areas to buy additional health packs or ammo, and the game has multiple endings based on a couple of important choices you make as a player. This sort of innovation boggles my mind for 1996, and it's even stranger to me that I had not even heard of this game until a few weeks ago.

The levels are scattered with secrets, the crux of which being 3 hidden talismans that the game makes you work like a dog for... When you finally get all three, your reward is... Well, I wont spoil it, but it was the most immensely satisfying prize you can imagine without being something inherently game ending. Strife also Gives you the option to stealth through most levels, again, one of the first FPSes that let you do this. The stealth is a little bit confusing, and isn't explained well, but hey, back in those days games came with a manual. Basically, most new areas bad guys wont consider you a threat until you open fire on them. A reasonable reaction, in my opinion. You can stop the alarms going off by killing secluded enemies with silent weapons; daggers or poison darts so that the inevitable dog-pile of enemies becomes easier to manage when they catch you being a ♥♥♥♥. You can also... you know... just complete your objective and leave without harming anyone; an option that I doubt many people took in 1996, but an option that is mandatory for the bloodbath difficulty which is as to NIGHTMARE mode what the Holocaust is to a teletubbies marathon. Bloodbath is horrendously difficult. I can finish any level of DOOM on nightmare mode but I cant get out of the first ROOM alive on bloodbath.

The protagonist has a hardcore sidekick named blackbird who, again, in a profound innovation is the first character I have ever heard say the F-word in a video game (chronologically, I mean), which endeared her to me immediately, her ultimate role is a shoehorned love interest but hey it's the nineties, too much innovation and they would have been burned at the steak. The protagonist himself is a relatively nameless, voiceless link character who travels through 20+ levels with a stunning variety of weapons from the humble bread and butter assault rifle to the double-barreled High-Explosive grenade launcher with optional white phosphorous rounds for when you're feeling frisky. Seriously the grenade launcher is in my top 3 weapons from all games, it is an immensely satisfying, unnecessarily powerful death machine.

The bosses are good, though the only two worth mentioning are the first boss and the last boss. The first boss is a hectic fast paced battle that I barely survived, the last battle was a wonderfully cinematic ultimatum. All the other bosses get one-shot by the stupid sigil weapon (think soul cube from doom 3). This is probably the only nit-pick I have with this game. The enemies are all astounding, peons, mechs and monsters are all well-rounded and have individual character Bosses, enemies and allies are all competently voice acted, my favourite being the snarky peon administrator who just takes one look at the amount of work you went through cheating yourself into the Order's main HQ, sighs, shrugs and waves you through.

Strife is challenging, rewards exploration and proactive thinking, the levels are well designed, it has character, atmosphere, and a satisfying conclusion with loads of wonderful comic book cutscenes. From 1996, this game is exceptional, and if you adjust for inflation, it is phoenominal. If you enjoy First-person games, you OWE it to yourself to play Strife.

mShuey
41 products in account
1 review
Recommended
7.1 hrs on record
Posted: May 24
A real gem of a game. I was in the market for a Doom style game so randomly got this game. It was the best choice I made that week. I found a game that had style, charm, intrigue, and a broad sense of challenge. Within the first hour I dead ended myself by just following the game. It was awesome once I realized I did it, the game didn't trick me into it. I even had suspicions about what I was doing as I did it. I still did it. Reloaded and went a different route. Then I started wondering where the Doom was in this supposed Doom style game.

Then I got to the first actual boss and it all came together. Its got the movement and shooting of doom, the hubworld of zelda games, the humor and style of comix zone. The remaster has a wealth of options to make it 'feel' modern without taking away its classic charm (that I sought it out for). You can experience it as it was released, or essentially emulated with modern filters for smoothing and design sensibilities, or any personal combo between the both.

In a day of making games fail proof to ensure no gamer gets left behind, this gamer was delighted to die in an endless wave of enemies because he listened to the first shlomo to give him a quest.

Azriel87

Recommended
8.7 hrs on record
Posted: July 18
If you think that it just another Doom clone from 1996 then you are wrong and doing this game a great disservice.
From first look it does look like your typical Doom-like FPS but when you start playing you will realize that is more of a RPG with great shouting mechanics used one the Doom engine.
This is game was brought back from the grave of games that the code was lost to them with reverse-engineering and got facelift by improving the visuals and sound -the enhanced Edition is a must buy.
Very good shooter with a good storyline and satisfactory voice acting, your choices can lead you up to 4 endings, secrets to find and fun to be had – so good luck!

Aarontu
390 products in account
39 reviews
Recommended
5.7 hrs on record
Posted: October 12
Strife: Veteran Edition is a modernized re-release of the original Strife, with bug fixes, slightly improved graphics, and modern controls. Strife is an odd hybrid type of game; it's a FPS running on the original DOOM engine, with RPG elements and an actual plot. The setting has an odd sci-fi-with-medieval-fantasy-and-Star-Wars-influences feel. The maps feel like a mix between open, realistic architecture (e.g. the Castle, the Commons) and tight, gamey, areas that feel thrown together (e.g. all the hub areas). It has one sidequest that makes the game unwinnable if you complete, which is annoying (at least the sidequest is at the start of the game so you can restart once you realize your current save is broken). And the ending is just so... cringeworthy.

Overall, the game is pretty mediocre, but still fun and I enjoyed it for what it is. It helps that the game is on the Doom engine and the gameplay is nice and fluid, even if all the other parts of the game are pretty lame or just average.
